title: 104_hr1497
content: The Act titled "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" revises the limitation on the deduction of policyholder dividends by mutual life insurance companies. The Act "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" amends the deduction limitation for policyholder dividends by mutual life insurance companies. The amendment specifies that the deduction for any taxable year shall not exceed 90% of policyholder dividends or 30% of the life insurance company taxable income, without considering any deduction for policyholder dividends. The limitation for dividends paid by a company during a taxable year is either 90% of policyholder dividends or 30% of the company's taxable income, with a minimum limit of $35,000,000. Stock life insurance companies are treated as mutual if at least 80% of voting stock is owned by mutual companies. The paragraph discusses the treatment of stock life insurance companies as mutual if a certain percentage of voting stock is owned by mutual companies. Section 809 of the Code is repealed. The repeal of Section 809 of the Code affects the treatment of stock life insurance companies owned by mutual companies. Amendments are made to sections 807 and 812 of the Code regarding policyholders' share of tax-exempt interest. Amendments are made to sections 807, 812, 817, and 842 of the Code regarding policyholders' share of tax-exempt interest and other related provisions. The effective date for these changes is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1994. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1994. These changes do not affect the application of section 809(f) for years before January 1, 1995. Capital losses after December 31, 1994, cannot be carried back to years before January 1, 1995 for certain life insurance companies. Small life insurance companies are exempt from capitalizing certain policy acquisition expenses starting after December 31, 1994. This exemption is defined for small life insurance companies as per section 806. Additionally, there is a sense of Congress relating to the use of increased revenues. The Congress intends that any additional revenue generated by the amendments in this Act should be allocated towards deficit reduction, tax incentives for small life insurance companies, and programs benefiting children's nutrition, education, housing, and family support.
